I wanted to use Event at first, but then the question became "how often should the child be emitting an update"? Since the constraint component is separate from the question input component, you can't trigger on change? Unless the flow goes: OnChange, response input (child) emit to question component (parent) -> question component (parent) emit to constraint component (child) -> constraint to question -> question (child) to submission form (parent)
The above flow felt more convoluted than just having an optional ViewChild. But I see now that my current implementation is not extendable to include validation for other questions. I will try and think about how I can use Event with a consideration for extensibility.
This is better suited as a interface which every *-constraint should override.
This is your starting point and should be where you fire the isValid event. Then your question becomes when should I fire the event? -> When the input changes? -> How can I know if the input changes?
This seems quite complex, I think I will remove the front-end validation from this PR and work on it in another PR so the UAT fix can get pushed out first. Thanks for all the guidance!

Same here:
Violation: Event should be used for parent-child communication
Ideally, there should be a event stream from the child component (that keep firing whether the input is valid or not) and here we just need to aggregate them (maybe reducer in rxjs).
Thought, honestly I am 100% sure it will works and need some research on this.
Do you have any starting point I could go about to research this? I'm actually not sure how multiple optional event streams can be subscribed to much less aggregated
I think there is no need to show error-specific message here (as they have been shown in the constraint). Just disable the submission button and say "please check the constrains" or something.
It will be a huge chaining if-else if we want to extend this to other question.
If you abstract others, why not do it for this also? isAllPointsDistributed?

nodes.bodyText: I think the problem here is the check (not the empty array thing). The check says that if user want to delete the response, they can use backspace to delete the answer (though it is not possible to pass the constraint check). If event is 0 which is valid answer, it will incorrectly enter this branch as !0 is true in JavaScript.

The check says that if user want to delete the response, they can use backspace to delete the answer

This should not be possible/allowed because the response is part of a larger question set. Deleting an option (currently represented as a response) while still allowing other options to be present should not logically be possible as they collectively constitute an answer set. This is my opinion anyway.
If I'm not wrong, since this method is only triggered onChange, it will not set the answer to 0 unless a change was made by the user. This should be a sufficient enough condition to indicate that the user wanted to give the 0 response. Additionally, with the placeholder, there is sufficient visual feedback to the user that the response is not 'empty' per se.

Then I think the correct fix is to remove the check. I think we should also remove the placeholder (see below).
Here are the correct behaviors in my mind:

User leaves it as blank -> nothing being stored (which is why the placeholder thing should be removed or will be mis-interpreted)
User enters zero (will treat it as valid response) (because of the removal of the check)
User cannot delete submitted response for the question (which follows your reasoning)
I see okay, yes that makes more sense thank you for the explanation
